awd_titl_txt: ELT Collaborative Research: Causes and effects of the Permian-Triassic biotic crisis inferred from continental margin sections and modelling
awd_abstract_narration:
The end-Permian mass extinction (EPME) was the most severe biotic crisis in the past 540 million years of Earth history. This project aims to identify the timing, nature, and causes of paleoenvironmental stresses leading up to and following the EPME, focusing on well-exposed sedimentary successions exposed in eastern Australia, and supported by climate modelling studies. The project will integrate data from several disciplines to explore the hypotheses that a) the EPME was part of a longer-term crisis that followed earlier events in the Middle-Late Permian, b) the crisis was not manifested simultaneously across the paleolatitudes, and c) continental ecosystems responded to the crisis in different ways than marine ecosystems. Students will be trained and public displays will be developed at the University of Nebraska State Museum.

The EPME has gained relevance as an example of an end-member ecological catastrophe that could potentially be replicated in the future. Coastal settings are among the most densely populated today, yet previous studies of the EPME have focused largely on oceanic and continental interior records. In investigating deposits that accumulated along ~2000 km of coastline spanning temperate to polar latitudes, the proposed project will improve understanding of the response of continental margins to rapid environmental change. This work will potentially transform understanding of the timeframes, driving mechanisms, global variability, and ultimate causes of the most severe global ecologic crisis of the Phanerozoic.

por.por_cntn:
Causes and effects of the Permian-Triassic biotic crisis from continental margin sections and modelling

C.R. Fielding (University of Nebraska-Lincoln) and others

This project was designed to determine the responses of earth surface systems in what is now eastern Australia to ancient environmental stresses at the end of the Permian period. Globally, this was a time of major disruption to the earth’s surface, and it entailed extinction of a majority of plant and animal life both on land and in the oceans. We sought to understand the nature, timing, and succession of environmental perturbances affecting the high southern latitudes at this time. We did this by studying successions of sedimentary rocks and their contained fossils exposed at the surface and recovered from the subsurface in drill cores in the Sydney and Bowen Basins of New South Wales and Queensland, respectively, and by conducting computer simulations of ancient climate based on the known distribution and shape of the continents at the time. We found evidence for a profound and abrupt extinction of the ancient Glossopteris flora at a time that preceded the end of the Permian period by 200,000-600,000 years. This is significant because it also predates the extinction event in the world’s ancient oceans by the same amount of time, indicating that life on land was adversely affected some considerable time before life in the oceans. We found that the ancient sedimentary environment in the Sydney and Bowen Basins, which was a broad, flat, coastal plain, changed only briefly at the time of the plant extinction, becoming flooded before then evolving gradually towards warmer and dryer conditions. We found elevated concentrations of heavy metals in sediments, suggesting that volcanic activity may have been responsible for poisoning plant life via dispersal of toxic aerosols. For some thousands of years after this, algae and fungi dominated plant life, until new plant forms were able to revegetate the devastated landscape. Complete recovery of earth surface systems took many millions of years to achieve.
